importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Millennium Seed Bank was opened by The Prince of Wales in 2000, marking its founding and establishing its role in global plant conservation.
The seed bank helped restore plants after intense wildfires in Australia in 2019, demonstrating its practical role in disaster recovery.
The article was published on October 19, 2025, highlighting the 25th anniversary milestone of the Millennium Seed Bank and its ongoing relevance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 25-year timeline from 2000 to 2025 underscores the long-term sustainability and expanding impact of the Millennium Seed Bank’s conservation efforts.

keyTakeAways: The Millennium Seed Bank (MSB) at Wakehurst, UK, is a global conservation project that stores over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species.
The MSB was opened in 2000 by The Prince of Wales and now plays a vital role in restoring degraded ecosystems around the world.
The bank's seed collection is used not just as a backup against extinction, but actively to restore habitats such as chalk grasslands in the South Downs and tropical forests globally.
Cate Blanchett, a Hollywood actress, has become a public ambassador for the MSB, engaging with the project and gaining hands-on experience in seed storage and conservation.
The project offers hope in the face of climate change, biodiversity loss, and extreme natural events like Australian wildfires.
The seed bank helps safeguard plant species that may hold future medicinal or environmental value, especially those lost due to deforestation and climate change.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cate Blanchett, a globally acclaimed Hollywood actress, has taken a passionate interest in environmental conservation by becoming an ambassador for the Kew Gardens Millennium Seed Bank (MSB), which celebrates its 25th anniversary. The MSB, opened in 2000 by The Prince of Wales, stores over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species and plays a vital role in restoring degraded habitats worldwide, including chalk grasslands in the South Downs and tropical forests. The project, originally conceived as a 'doomsday vault' to protect against extinction, now actively supports ecological recovery after events like Australia's 2019 bushfires. Through hands-on engagement, Blanchett has learned about seed storage and conservation, demonstrating how public figures can amplify scientific initiatives. The article highlights how the MSB not only safeguards biodiversity but also offers hope in the face of climate change and environmental destruction, reinforcing its role as a vital global conservation effort.
title: Cate Blanchett: In praise of the humble seed
